entry.title: Python
entry.content:
最近瞭解一個複式記賬軟件 Beancount。瞭解它的過程在發現，它是使用 python 寫成的記賬軟件。現在上手 Beancount 明顯門檻有點高，兼具會計知識和編程知識。但是自己在編程語言上的認知上是一窮二白。如今慢慢意識到，在高度計算化的時代背景下，還是得要學一門計算機語言。不僅要瞭解計算機語言，還要瞭解計算機科學。這一切，就從 python 學起吧。

在網絡找了阿里雲的 python 免費課程，尋找資源的過程中，發現在網絡上有許多系統的計算機學習課程，不由感嘆，資源的便利。選擇的理由是阿里雲這塊牌子下所代表的質量把控。後才知道，這不是阿里雲的自身出的課程，而是出自計算機教育機構尚硅谷之手。從20號開始看，講得通俗易懂，從最簡單的概念出發。比在學校裡上的 python 課程更易上手，至少我是這麼覺得的。我很喜歡這個老師的授課方式。

不論是計算機編程語言，漢語、英語等人類自然語言，數理邏輯中的邏輯語言，本質上還是傳達信息的語言。故初始階段不要把編程語言的預設難度拔得過高，這僅是一門語言「Language」。

entry.content:
MAP BY ANTONIO DE HERRERA Y TORDESILLAS, COURTESY THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS

 

​ The world map shows the boundary line between the spheres of influence of the world’s first great powers in 15th century, Spain and Portugal. entry.content:
觀影『1944』，戰爭片，愛沙尼亞人對本民族20世紀苦難的緬念。

這是部好電影，沒有歌功頌德、沒有凸顯崇拜，比陳凱歌大導演向主子獻禮的抗美神劇《長津湖》強一萬倍。

片中有個細節很有意思，加入德軍的愛沙尼亞年輕人當著上級的面否定著對元首的個人崇拜，拿著上級賞賜的希特勒照片竭盡所能地諷刺與嘲笑。

大家都是兩條腿一個頭，活不到150歲的人，難道因為你是當政者在上帝面前就高我一等？

1941年蘇聯吞併愛沙尼亞，同年德國出兵愛沙尼亞。1944年德軍退出愛沙尼亞，蘇軍再次佔領愛沙尼亞。故事發生在此時。

同歷史一樣，這裡再次成為歐洲和俄羅斯的交鋒前線。

愛沙尼亞的地理位置使其難逃地緣政治鬥爭的厄運。二戰期間，德意志人和斯拉夫人在波羅的海畔相遇，5萬多愛沙尼亞人加入蘇軍，7萬多人加入德軍。流的是愛沙尼亞人的血，身上穿的卻是蘇軍或德軍的軍裝。

大國角力下的同胞相殺。

實際上，二戰後，愛沙尼亞一直在蘇聯的控制之下。直到蘇聯解體前夕。愛沙尼亞才得以在本國國土上升起藍黑白國旗。

蘇聯解體是人類文明之幸事。

entry.title: Can Radio Really Educate
entry.content:
午時，讀文章 Can Radio Really Educate。廣播在美國帶來的教育進步。文章中提到，數據時代的“遠程學習”理念在電磁波時代就已經出現了。有點幽默~

每次新科技的出現總會帶來一定的社會憂慮，也會受到負面評價，但把視角拉長來看，也阻止不了其應用。

現在的人很難想到，當年收音機在美國剛出現時，處理科技帶來新奇感之外，還有其他今天看來也熟悉十分的感受。雜誌編輯擔心人們越來越少人買雜誌；老師們擔心學生大腦成為其他聲音的跑馬場；音樂家擔心人們不再會去現場音樂會；教父們擔心如果佈道形式轉換為廣播的話，那麼教堂是不是就失去意義了。

種種擔心的形式在現在看來也是如此熟悉。家長擔心網絡遊戲毀了孩子；執政黨擔心遊戲會佔用孩子們讀紅寶書的時間；趙家人擔心孩子學英文、翻牆看外網會啟蒙他們的心智。

太陽底下沒有新鮮事，當下的時事熱事總會成為未來人的笑談。

entry.title: Big Assumption with Conditional and Indirect Proofs
entry.content:
Conditional proof and indirect proof involve an assumption, which is an additional premise that you don’t know is true but you assume is true.

Conditional Proof

Understanding conditional proof

Conditional proof allows you to use part of the conclusion as a premise that you can use to prove the rest of the conclusion.

To prove the validity of an argument whose conclusion is in the form x → y (that is, any →-statement), you can follow these steps:

  1. Detach the sub-statement x.
  2. Add x to your list of premises as an assumed premise (AP).
  3. Prove the sub-statement y as if it were the conclusion.

 

egin{align*}P ightarrow eg Q, P \vee eg R: Q ightarrow (( eg P \wedge eg R) \vee Q ightarrow P)\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ightarrow eg Q ag P\&2 \quad P \vee eg R ag { P }\&3 \quad Q ag{ AP}\&4 \quad eg P ag{ 1,3 MT }\&5\quad eg R ag{ 2,4 DS }\&6\quad eg P \wedge eg R ag{ 4,5 Conj }\&7 \quad ( eg P \wedge eg R) \vee (Q ightarrow P) ag { 6 Add }\&8 \quad Q ightarrow (( eg P\wedge eg R) \vee (Q ightarrow P) ag { 3,7 CP }\end{align*}

 

Flipping conclusion with Contra

To take full advantage of this section, you have to first remember that you can use every →-statement in two ways: The way it is and in its Contra form.

 

egin{align*}P ightarrow Q, R \vee (Q ightarrow P): eg (P \leftrightarrow Q) ightarrow R\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ightarrow Q ag { p }\&2 \quad R \vee (Q ightarrow P) ag { p }\&3 \quad eg R ag{ AP }\&4 \quad Q ightarrow P ag{ 2,3 DS }\&5\quad (P ightarrow Q) \wedge (Q ightarrow P) ag{ P }\&6\quad P \leftrightarrow Q ag{5 Equiv }\&7 \quad eg R ightarrow (P \leftrightarrow Q) ag {3-6 CP }\&8 \quad eg (P \leftrightarrow Q) ightarrow R ag { 7 Contra }\end{align*}

 

Winning through implication

You can also turn any ∨\vee∨-statement into a →-statement by using Impl . Using Impl makes any 0-statement a potential candidate for conditional proof.

 

egin{align*}P: eg R\vee(Q ightarrow(P\wedge R))\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ag { P }\&2 \quad R\wedge Q ag { AP }\&3 \quad R ag{ 2 Simp }\&4 \quad P \wedge R ag{ 1,3 Conj }\&5\quad (P \wedge Q ) ightarrow(P\wedge Q) ag{ 2-4 CP }\&6\quad R ightarrow(Q ightarrow(P\wedge R)) ag{ 5 Exp }\&7 \quad eg R \vee (Q ightarrow(P\wedge R)) ag { 6 Impl }\end{align*}

 

Stacking assumptions

After you assume a premise, if the new conclusion is a →-statement (or can be turned into one), you can assume another premise. This is nice way to get two (or more!) assumptions for the price of one. Here’s an example:

egin{align*} eg Q \vee R: (P\vee R) ightarrow ((Q\wedge S) ightarrow (R\wedge S))\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad eg Q \vee R ag { P }\&2 \quad (P\vee R) ag { AP }\&3 \quad Q\wedge S ag{ AP }\&4 \quad Q ag{3 Simp }\&5 \quad S ag{3 Simp }\&6 \quad R ag{ 1,4 DS}\&7 \quad R \wedge S ag { 5.6 Conj }\&8 \quad (Q\wedge S) ightarrow (R\wedge S) ag { 3-7 CP }\&9 \quad (P\vee R) ightarrow ((Q\wedge S) ightarrow (R\wedge S)) ag{ 2-8 CP }\end{align*}

 

 

Indirect Proof

Introducing indirect proof

Indirect proof (also called proof by contradiction) is a type of logical judo. The idea here is to assume that the conclusion is false and then show why this assumption is wrong. Success means that your conclusion was true all along.

To prove that any argument is valid, you can follow these steps:

  1. Negate the conclusion.
  2. Add the negation to your list of premises as an assumption.
  3. Prove any contradictory statement (any statement of the form x∧¬xx \wedge eg xx∧¬x).

 

egin{align*}P ightarrow(Q\wedge eg R), R: eg (P\vee eg R)\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ightarrow(Q\wedge eg R) ag { P }\&2 \quad R ag { P }\&3 \quad P\vee eg R ag{ AP }\end{align*}

Your goal now is to prove a statement and its negation, then use them to build a contradictory ∧\wedge∧-statement, like this:

egin{align*}\&4 \quad P ag{ 2,3 DS }\&5\quad Q \wedge eg R ag{ 1,4 MP }\&6\quad eg R ag{ Simp }\end{align*}

At this point, you’ve derived both R and ¬R eg R¬R, so you can build them into a single contradictory statement as follows:

egin{align*}\&7 \quad R\wedge eg R ag { 2,6 Conj }\end{align*}

The assumption has led to an impossible situation, so you know that the AP must be false. If P∨¬RP\vee eg RP∨¬R is false, then ¬(P∨¬R) eg (P\vee eg R)¬(P∨¬R) must be true:

egin{align*}&8 \quad eg (P\vee eg R) ag { 3-7 IP }\end{align*}

Proving short conclusions

As I mention in Chapter 9, arguments where the conclusion is shorter than the premises tend to be more difficult to prove than those where the conclusion is longer, because breaking down long premises can be tricky.

However, indirect proof works especially well when the conclusion is shorter than the premises because the negated conclusion becomes a nice short premise for you to use. For example, consider this argument:

egin{align*} eg (( eg P \vee Q)\wedge R) ightarrow S,P\vee eg R, eg Q \vee S:S\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad eg (( eg P \vee Q)\wedge R) ightarrow S ag { P }\&2 \quad P\vee eg R ag { P }\&3 \quad eg Q \vee S ag{ P }\&4 \quad eg S ag{AP }\&5 \quad ( eg P \vee Q) \wedge R ag{ 1,4 MT }\&6 \quad eg P \vee Q ag{5 Simp }\&7 \quad R ag { 5 Simp }\&8 \quad P ag { 2,7 DS }\&9 \quad Q ag{ 6,8 DS }\&10 \quad S ag{ 3,9 DS }\end{align*}

Remember: When you’re doing an indirect proof, don’t be fooled into thinking you’re done after you prove the conclusion. Remember that you also need to build a contradictory statement.

In this case, the AP leads to its own negation, which allows you to complete the proof:

egin{align*}\&11 \quad S \wedge eg S ag { 4,10 Conj }\&12 \quad S ag { 4-11 CP}\end{align*}

Superficially, line 12 looks like line 10, but now you’ve discharged the AP, so the proof is complete.

 

Combining Conditional and Indirect Proofs

egin{align*} eg P \wedge Q ightarrow( eg R \wedge S), Q: R ightarrow P\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad eg P \wedge Q ightarrow( eg R \wedge S) ag { P }\&2 \quad Q ag { P }\&3 \quad eg ( eg P \wedge Q) \vee ( eg R \wedge S) ag{1 Impl }\&4 \quad R ag{AP (for conditional proof) }\&5 \quad eg P ag{AP (for indirect proof) }\end{align*}

Now the goal is to find a contradiction:

egin{align*}\&6 \quad eg P \wedge Q ag{ 2,5 Conj }\&7 \quad eg R \wedge S ag { 1,6 MP }\&8 \quad eg R ag { 7 Simp }\end{align*}

Now you’re ready to discharge the AP for the indirect proof:

egin{align*}\&9 \quad R\wedge eg R ag{ 4,8 Conj }\&10 \quad P ag{ 5-9 IP }\&11 \quad R ightarrow P ag{4-10 CP }\end{align*}

When using conditional and indirect proof methods together, discharge your APs starting with the last one you added (here, AP of indirect proof is the last one) and work your way back to the first.
entry.summary: Conditional proof and indirect proof involve an assumption, which is an additional premise that you don’t know is true but you assume is true.

entry.title: 18 Rules of Inference in SL
entry.content:
Eight Implication Rules

The → ightarrow→ rules: Modus Ponens and Modus Tollens

MP:

egin{align*}x→y, x : y\end{align*}

MT:

egin{align*}x→y, eg y: eg x\end{align*}

 

The ∧\wedge∧ rules: Conjunction and Simplification

Conj:

egin{align*}x, y : x \wedge y\end{align*}

Simp:

egin{align*}x \wedge y: x\x \wedge y: y\end{align*}

 

The ∨\vee∨ rules: Addition and Disjunctive Syllogism

Add:

egin{align*}x : x \vee y\end{align*}

DS:

egin{align*}x \vee y , eg x : y\x \vee y , eg y : x\end{align*}

 

The double → ightarrow→ rules: Hypothetical Syllogism and Constructive Dilemma

HS:

egin{align*}x→y, y→z : x→z\end{align*}

CD:

egin{align*}w \vee x, w→y, x→z : y \vee z\end{align*}

 

Ten Valid Equivalences

The double-colon symbol ::, when placed between two statements, this symbol means that the two statements are equivalent — that is, you can substitute one for the other whenever needed.

 

Double Negation (DN)

egin{align*}x :: eg eg x\end{align*}

Contraposition (Contra)

egin{align*}x ightarrow y :: eg y ightarrow eg x\end{align*}

Implication (Impl)

When you know that the statement x → y is true, you know that either x is false (that is, ¬x eg x¬x is true) or that y is true. In other words, you know that the statement ¬x∨y eg x \vee y¬x∨y is true.

egin{align*}x ightarrow y :: eg x \vee y\end{align*}

 

xyx→yx ightarrow yx→y¬x∨y eg x \vee y¬x∨y
TTTT
TFFF
FTTT
FFTT

Example:

egin{align*}P ightarrow Q, P \vee R: Q \vee R\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ightarrow Q ag P\&2 \quad P \vee R ag P\&3 \quad eg P \vee Q ag{1 Impl}\&4 \quad eg Q ightarrow eg P ag{1 Contra}\&5 \quad eg P ightarrow R ag{2 Impl}\&6 \quad eg R ightarrow P ag{2 Contra}\&7 \quad eg Q ightarrow R ag{4,5 HS}\&8 \quad Q \vee R ag{7 Impl}\end{align*}

Exportation (Exp)

egin{align*}x ightarrow (y ightarrow z)::(x\wedge y) ightarrow z\end{align*}

Example:

(P∧Q)→R,¬R∨S,P:Q→S(P\wedge Q) ightarrow R, eg R \vee S,P:Q ightarrow S(P∧Q)→R,¬R∨S,P:Q→S

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad (P\wedge Q) ightarrow R ag P\&2 \quad eg R \vee S ag P\&3 \quad p ag{1 Impl}\&4 \quad P ightarrow (Q ightarrow R) ag{1 Exp}\&5\quad Q ightarrow R ag{3,4 MP}\&6\quad R ightarrow S ag{2 Impl}\&7\quad Q ightarrow S ag{5,6 HS}\end{align*}

Commutation (Comm)

egin{align*}x \wedge y ::y \wedge x\x \vee y::y \vee x\end{align*}

Example:

egin{align*}P \wedge ( eg Q ightarrow R):(R \vee Q) \wedge P\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P \wedge ( eg Q ightarrow R) ag P\&2 \quad P ag {1 Simp}\&3 \quad eg Q ightarrow R ag{1 Simp}\&4 \quad Q \vee R ag{3 Impl}\&5\quad R \vee Q ag{4 Comm}\&6\quad (R \vee Q ) \wedge P ag{5 Conj}\end{align*}

 

Association (Assoc)

egin{align*}(x \wedge y ) \wedge z:: x \wedge ( y\wedge z)\(x \vee y )\vee z:: x \vee ( y\vee z)\end{align*}

Example:

egin{align*}(P ightarrow Q) \vee R : Q\vee (R \vee eg P)\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad (P ightarrow Q) ag P\&2 \quad ( eg P \vee Q) \vee R ag { 1 Impl }\&3 \quad (Q \vee eg P) \vee R ag{ 2 Comm }\&4 \quad Q \vee ( eg P \vee R) ag{ 3 Assoc }\&5\quad Q \vee (R \vee eg P) ag{ 4 Comm }\end{align*}

 

Distribution (Dist)

I have a pet and it’s either a cat or a dog. x∧(y∨z)x \wedge ( y \vee z)x∧(y∨z)

Either I have a pet and it’s a cat or I have a pet and it’s a dog. (x∧y)∨(x∧z)(x \wedge y) \vee( x \wedge z)(x∧y)∨(x∧z)

I have to take either organic chemistry or both botany and zoology. x∨(y∧z)x \vee ( y \wedge z)x∨(y∧z)

I have to take either organic chemistry or botany, and I also have to take either organic chemistry or zoology. (x∨y)∧(x∨z)(x \vee y) \wedge( x \vee z)(x∨y)∧(x∨z)

egin{align*}x \wedge ( y \vee z) :: (x \wedge y) \vee( x \wedge z)\x \vee ( y \wedge z) :: (x \vee y) \wedge( x \vee z)\end{align*}

 

Example:

egin{align*}Q \vee R, eg ( P \wedge Q), P: R\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad Q \vee R ag P\&2 \quad eg ( P \wedge Q) ag { P }\&3 \quad P ag{ P }\&4 \quad P \wedge (Q \vee R ) ag{ 1,3 Conj }\&5\quad (P \wedge Q)\vee ( P \wedge R) ag{ 4 Dist }\&6\quad P \wedge R ag{ 2,5 DS }\&7\quad R ag{6 Simp}\end{align*}

DeMorgan’s Theorem (DeM)

egin{align*} eg (x\wedge y) :: eg x \vee eg y\ eg (x\vee y) :: eg x \wedge eg y\end{align*}

 

It’s not true that I’m both rich and famous. ¬(x∧y) eg (x\wedge y)¬(x∧y)

Either I’m not rich or I’m not famous. ¬x∨¬y eg x \vee eg y¬x∨¬y

Jack is neither a doctor nor a lawyer. $ eg (x\vee y) $

Jack isn’t a doctor and he isn’t a lawyer. ¬x∧¬y eg x \wedge eg y¬x∧¬y

 

Example:

egin{align*}Q \vee R, eg (P\wedge Q), P:R\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad Q \vee R ag p\&2 \quad eg (P\wedge Q) ag { p }\&3 \quad P ag{ p }\&4 \quad eg P \vee eg Q ag{2 DeM }\&5\quad eg Q ag{3,4 DS}\&6\quad R ag{ 1,5 DS }\end{align*}

Tautology (Taut)

egin{align*}x\wedge x ::x\x \vee x::x\end{align*}

Example:

egin{align*}P ightarrow eg P: eg P\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P ightarrow eg P ag P\&2 \quad eg P \vee eg P ag {1 Impl }\&3 \quad eg P ag{ 2 Taut }\end{align*}

Equivalence (Equiv)

egin{align*}x \leftrightarrow y &::(x ightarrow y ) \wedge (y ightarrow x)\x \leftrightarrow y &::(x\wedge y)\vee ( eg x \wedge eg y)\end{align*}

Example 1:

egin{align*}P \leftrightarrow (Q\wedge R), Q: P\vee eg R\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P \leftrightarrow (Q\wedge R) ag P\&2 \quad Q ag { P }\&3 \quad (P ightarrow (Q \wedge R)) \wedge ((Q \wedge R) ightarrow P) ag{ 1 Equiv }\&4 \quad (P \wedge (Q \wedge R)) \vee ( eg P \wedge eg (Q \wedge R)) ag{ 1 Equiv }\&5\quad P ightarrow (Q \wedge R) ag{ 3 Simp }\&6\quad (Q \wedge R) ightarrow P ag{ 3 Simp }\&7 \quad Q ightarrow ( R ightarrow P) ag {6 Exp}\&8 \quad R ightarrow P ag {2,7 MP }\&9 \quad eg R \vee P ag{ 8 Impl }\&10 \quad P \vee eg R ag{9 Comm }\end{align*}

 

Example 2:

egin{align*}P \leftrightarrow Q, R ightarrow (P \vee Q):R ightarrow (P \wedge Q)\end{align*}

Proof:

egin{align*}&1 \quad P \leftrightarrow Q ag {P}\&2 \quad R ightarrow (P \vee Q) ag { P }\&3 \quad (P ightarrow Q) \wedge (Q ightarrow P) ag{ 1 Equiv }\&4 \quad (P \wedge Q) \vee ( eg P ightarrow eg Q) ag{ 1 Equiv }\&5\quad P ightarrow Q ag{3 Simp}\&6\quad Q ightarrow P ag{3 Simp }\&7 \quad eg (P \wedge Q) ightarrow ( eg P \wedge eg Q) ag {4 Impl}\&8 \quad eg ( eg P \wedge eg Q) ightarrow (P \wedge Q) ag { 7 Contra }\&9 \quad (P\vee Q) ightarrow (P \wedge Q) ag{ 8 DeM }\&10 \quad R ightarrow (P \wedge Q) ag{ 2,9 HS }\end{align*}
